agreement name: DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement
notes_1: "Negotiations between the Sudanese government and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army (SPLM/A) took place for the first time on 31 July 1986, when John Garang and Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi met for talks in which the two key demands of the SLPM/A were discussed: the suspension of the Sharia and the termination of military pacts with Libya and Egypt. However, on 16 August 1986, the peace talks were suspended due to the SPLM/A bombing a civil airplane, which resulted in the death of 60 passengers. Egypt – in spite of its military support to the Government of Sudan – managed to facilitate contacts between the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and SPLM/A in the mid-1988. The DUP was one of the three parties in Khartoum’s ruling coalition. Ethiopia subsequently offered to host talks in Addis Ababa between the DUP and the SPLM/A. This led to the signing of what has been referred to as the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement on 16 November 1988 by DUP leader Mohamed Osman al-Mirghani and SPLM/A leader John Garang de Mabior. However, the agreement soon collapsed as a result of an internal power struggle within the Government of Sudan. The opposition in the coalition government, the National Islamic Front (NIF), did not accept the peace agreement, as it wished to maintain Islamic law and refused to abrogate military pacts with Egypt and Libya. The NIF denounced the talks as a conspiracy to block Islamic law. Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi voted down a DUP amendment to recognise the terms of the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement. Consequently, the DUP resigned from government on 27 December 1988. In March 1989, a new Government assumed power, which proposed a peace plan that was based on the peace deal that was reached between SPLM/A and DUP in November 1988, calling for a freeze on Islamic laws. The UN became involved in April 1989, trying to make both parties accept a ceasefire."

The DUP was one of the three parties in Khartoum’s ruling coalition. Ethiopia subsequently offered to host talks in Addis Ababa between the DUP and the SPLM/A. This led to the signing of what has been referred to as the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement on 16 November 1988 by DUP leader Mohamed Osman al-Mirghani and SPLM/A leader John Garang de Mabior. However, the agreement soon collapsed as a result of an internal power struggle within the Government of Sudan. The NIF denounced the talks as a conspiracy to block Islamic law. Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi voted down a DUP amendment to recognise the terms of the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement. Consequently, the DUP resigned from government on 27 December 1988. In March 1989, a new Government assumed power, which proposed a peace plan that was based on the peace deal that was reached between SPLM/A and DUP in November 1988, calling for a freeze on Islamic laws. The UN became involved in April 1989, trying to make both parties accept a ceasefire."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "At a meeting on 1 May 1989, the UN managed to convince the conflict parties observe a “month of tranquility” to allow aid to reach the area where people are threatened with famine. This ceasefire was later extended for another two weeks. The Government of Sudan subsequently accepted the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement, after which it was also ratified by the parliament."

"Following the collapse of the Carter initiative, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi invited Bashir and Garang to his Presidential retreat in Nakuru for peace talks. Both Bashir and Garang accepted the invitation and the meeting was set for 27 February 1990. However, at the last minute Garang decided not to go, so only Bashir showed up.  Similarly, Zaire and Egypt mediated in 1990, but could not bring the conflict parties to the negotiation table. The Government of Sudan took the initiative in March 1990 to request the US to mediate. The US subsequently initiated a mediation effort. In order to move the conflict parties towards a peace settlement, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Herman Cohen began to shuttle between the conflict parties in March 1990. Cohen formulated a proposal that stipulated the conclusion of a ceasefire, withdrawal of troops, followed by a constitutional conference that would decide on a federal system. With regard to the withdrawal of troops, Cohen proposed the complete evacuation of the national army to positions north of the 11th parallel, while the SPLM/A had to guarantee that it would not take control of southern Sudan militarily if the government forces would withdraw. With neither conflict party agreeing to this proposal, Cohen subsequently formulated a new proposal, which stipulated that half of the government forces would be pulled out from southern Sudan, while the SPLM/A would in exchange withdraw all its troops 15 kilometres from the besieged towns. Moreover, the withdrawal of troops would be internationally monitored. Cohen also proposed to hold a constitutional conference . Cohen personally presented the adapted proposal to President al-Bashir in Khartoum on 9 March 1990. While al-Bashir promised Cohen to study the proposal carefully, he soon conveyed that he rejected the possibility of a constitutional conference, preferring bilateral talks with John Garrang. The Government of Sudan also refused to withdraw from some garrison towns in areas controlled by the rebels including some oil fields.  This terminated his round of shuttle talks in March 1990. In May, Cohen again tried to imitate a peace conference, but the government side officially rejected this option on 4 June 1990."

"The mediation efforts of the US continued in early January 1991. Yet, diplomatic relations between the US and Sudan severely deteriorated due to the US military action against Iraq on 17 January 1991. As a result, the Sudanese-American dialogue felt silent. In March 1991, the Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) Salim Ahmed Salim offered his good offices to restart the peace process. Salim shuttled between the conflict parties and his efforts led to the conflict parties accepting mediation by the Organization of African Unity and Nigeria. Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, who assumed Organization of African Unity Chairmanship on 3 June 1991, acted as the chief mediator of these negotiations. In spite of separate consultations, Nigeria and the Organization of African Unity did not mediate any direct peace talks between the conflict parties in 1991. Although the negotiations were set to take place in the fall of 1991, they were postponed until May 1992 because of divisions within the ranks of the SPLM/A."

agreement name: Communique of the Abuja Sudanese Peace Conference
notes_1: "The first phase of what came to be known as the Abuja peace talks started on 26 May 1992 and ended on 4 June 1992 without any progress made. The talks were hosted by the Nigerian president Ibrahim Babangida in his capacity as chair of the Organization of African Unity. Talks focus particularly on issues related to national identity, religion and state, self-determination, and interim security arrangements. The Nigerian mediators suggested to the conflict parties that an effective ceasefire would require a neutral observer team that would ensure all the parties complied with the peace agreement. Although the SPLM/A agreed, the Government of Sudan insisted that such a team would constitute “foreign intervention in the affairs of Sudan.” The first phase of the Abuja negotiations ended with the adoption of the Communique of the Abuja Sudanese Peace Conference."

"The Sudanese peace talks in Abuja broke down and IGAD was invited to mediate. IGAD established a Standing Committee on Peace to facilitate neogitations and proposed a Declaration of Principles, which included partition as possible resolution to the conflict, which was accepted (though reluctantly) by the SPLM and rejected by the Khartoum government in 1994."

"IGAD hosted and sponsored several rounds of peace talks throughout 1994. Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi hosted the talks as chairman of IGAD. Preliminary shuttle peace talks were held in Nairobi in the beginning of January in order to determine the issues that would be put on the agenda for the formal talks."

agreement name: IGAD Declaration of Principles
notes_1: Since the conflict parties could not agree on an official agenda for negotiations, the IGAD mediation team drafted a Declaration of Principles (DoP) which the conflict parties were meant to review in preparation for a third round of negotiations in July 1994. The compromise envisioned in the DoP was that while the south would have the right to self-determination because of the high level of polarization in Sudan, priority should be given to unity to be created through a national consensus.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: Another round of negotiations was subsequently held in Nairobi between 18 and 28 July 1994. While the SPLM/A accepted the DoP, the government side rejected the document. Nevertheless, on 23 July 1994, the Government of Sudan declared a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire was initially rejected by SPLM/A, but was eventually accepted. The ceasefire was later broken, probably by both sides.

The parties met again for IGAD-sponsored negotiations in Nairobi between 5 and 7 September 1994, but the talks again ended in a deadlock. Earlier in the year, between May and July, various Western diplomatic initiatives were coordinated in a new grouping, named the Friends of IGAD. The goal of this contact group was to increase the leverage of the IGAD mediation efforts.

In 1995, former US president Jimmy Carter managed to conduct shuttle mediation between the conflict parties, which led to a two-month ceasefire that was unilaterally announced by the Government of Sudan on 28 March 1995. The two-month ceasefire would help a health campaign organized by the Carter Center against Guinea worm infestation and river blindness in the south.  In addition to the ceasefire, the rebels were offered amnesty if they laid down their weapons. The SPLM/A accepted the ceasefire two days later on 1 June 1995, although some elements within the organisation rejected the ceasefire. The SPLM/A also called for international monitoring of the ceasefire. According to Carter, the ceasefire was holding with a few minor exceptions. Yet, the conflict parties accused each other of violating the ceasefire. In August 1995, the conflict parties agreed to resume peace talks, but not to extend the ceasefire. Yet, the talks never took place.

agreement name: Asmara Declaration
notes_1: Eritrea’s Isaias Afwerki believed the Khartoum government would soon fall and expelled the Sudanese ambassador from Sudan’s embassy in Eritrea and handed it over to the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) of oppositionists, focussing on diplomatic connections with the NDA, which culminated with the Asmara Declaration of 1995. (Other: shift in diplomatic approach to engage with the opposition, in North Sudan, rather than Sudanese government in Khartoum).

notes_1: The Fashoda Relief and Rehabilitation Association (an SPLM-affiliated humanitarian organisation) worked alongside the UNICEF-led Operation Lifeline to negotiate and agree on standards of conduct vis-à-vis humanitarian operations in SPLM-controlled areas

South African President Nelson Mandela held separate discussions with the conflict parties and succeeded in initiating direct talks, which began on 28 August 1997 in Nairobi under the aegis of IGAD. These talks were chaired by Kenyan Foreign Minister Kalonzo Musyoka, but representatives of Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Uganda were all participating in the mediation process.

At this IGAD summit in Nairobi in July 1997, Kenyan President Moi succeeded in convincing President al-Bashir to finally accept the DoP and resume direct negotiations with the SPLM/A in October 1997.  While the IGAD mediators tried to push the conflict parties to discuss how the DoP could be transformed in a sustained negations process, the negotiations that were held in October 1997 remained deadlocked on the issue of secularism, but also on the modalities of a referendum and the length of the transition period. When talks broke down again, the IGAD mediators issue a communique on 11 November 1997, which stated that the IGAD mediators would shuttle between the adversaries, but that direct negotiations would be adjourned until April 1998

The conflict parties resumed peace talks in Nairobi on 4 May 1998, under the auspices of IGAD. Not wanting to appear as an obstructionist, the Sudanese government accepted self-determination for the south on the basis of a referendum during this round of talks.

Up until 1999, the Kenyan minister of Foreign Affairs had acted as the chief mediator of the peace talks, but it was decided in mid-1999 that a mediator needed to be appointed that could lead sustained negotiations. To this end, Daniel Mboya, the former Kenyan Ambassador to Sudan, was appointed. IGAD-sponsored peace talks were resumed in Nairobi on 20 July 1999. The parties agreed on procedural issues for further talks, but they failed to make any progress on substantial issues pertaining to a comprehensive ceasefire, self-determination for the south, defining a border, and the relation between religion and state.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: Additionally, the UN was also involved in mediation between the conflict parties in a round of shuttle negotiations in February 2000. The goal of this UN mediation effort was to conclude a humanitarian ceasefire to allow for the vaccination of 54,000 children in the Nuba mountains. This mediation effort was successful. The conflict parties agreed on a three-day ceasefire in February 2000.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: Another second three-day ceasefire was brokered in March 2000.

Another IGAD-mediated round of negotiations took place between 21 and 30 September 2000. During this round of peace talks, the mediators proposed a two-tier arrangement in which all institutions on a national level were to be neutral on religion. This proposal was accepted by the SPLM/A, but rejected by the Government of Sudan.

Another IGAD-mediated round of negotiations took place between 21 and 30 September 2000. During this round of peace talks, the mediators proposed a two-tier arrangement in which all institutions on a national level were to be neutral on religion. This proposal was accepted by the SPLM/A, but rejected by the Government of Sudan.

After the successful military coup of 30 June 1989, which replaced President Ahmed Ali al-Mirghani with President Omar el-Bashir, all political parties were banned, and strict Islamic legal codes were enforced. The coup led to the formation of an umbrella opposition group called the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). In 1990, the SPLM/A joined the NDA, which at the time was a non-militant opposition group. The NDA aimed to remove the regime and set up a democratic system in Sudan. The NDA further envisioned that as part of this new democratic system the people in the South would have the right to a referendum on self-determination. The NDA was fairly loosely organised, composed of a variety of different entities such as civil society organisations, as well as rebel groups. Groups taking part in the alliance have on several occasions acted on their own, both when it comes to negotiations with and fighting against the government. Until 1996, the NDA was a solely political platform, but in September 1996, the NDA decided to set up a joint military force. After this point the NDA was both an umbrella organisation and an organisation with its own military and commanders fighting under the NDA banner. The Sudan peace process led by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) solely included the government and the SPLM/A. Hence, the NDA as an alliance was excluded from all negotiations mediated by IGAD.  In July 1999, Libyan leader of state Muammar al-Gaddafi proposed a conference on national dialogue at a NDA meeting in Tripoli. Both the NDA leadership and the Sudanese government accepted to engage in negotiations mediated by Libya and Egypt. A five-point peace plan was subsequently presented by Libya and Egypt, which included the whole NDA in the process. This plan was welcomed by the NDA as the best comprehensive political solution to the civil war. The Government of Sudan also approved of the five-point plan. The Libyan-Egyptian peace initiative faced great obstacles due to Egypt’s opposition to self-determination for the south, which was one of the cornerstones of the IGAD peace process. Nevertheless, SPLM/A leader John Garang expressed his support for the Libyan-Egyptian initiative in principle, but called for a coordination with the IGAD process. In spite of the acceptance of the peace plan, no direct negotiations between the NDA and the Government of Sudan took place as part this initiative. No negotiations or mediation took place in 1999. Egypt mediated between the adversaries through separate meetings with representatives from the Government of Sudan and the leaders of the NDA. A round of shuttle negotiations between the conflict parties, mediated by Egypt, took place in Cairo in the spring of 2000.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: The Government of Sudan and the SPLM/A met for a week of talks in Buergenstock in January 2002. The mediation team included both American and Swiss diplomats and the Swiss Ambassador Josef Bucher acted as the chief mediator. After six days of negotiations, the conflict parties concluded a ceasefire pertaining to the Nuba Mountains on 19 January 2002. It was agreed that the ceasefire in Nuba Mountains would monitored by Britain, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Switzerland and the US. The peace talks in Switzerland were coordinated with IGAD and thus complementary to the IGAD-led peace process.
note_2: The Swiss Special Envoy for Conflict Issues, Josef Bucher, helped to negotiate and bore witness to the signing of the Nuba Mountains Ceasefire Agreement on Sudan on 19th January. Bucher was also mandated to seek humanitarian resolutions in the Sudan conflict.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: The Government of Sudan and the SPLM/A met for a week of talks in Buergenstock in January 2002. The peace talks in Switzerland were coordinated with IGAD and thus complementary to the IGAD-led peace process.
note_2: The US ambassador, Col. Cecil Dennis Giddens, bore witness to the signing of the Nuba Mountains Ceasefire Agreement on Sudan on 19th January. The US envoy also facilitated and participated in negotiations towards the ceasefire and was also mandated to seek humanitarian solutions to the Sudan crisis.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: The Government of Sudan and the SPLM/A met for a week of talks in Buergenstock in January 2002. The mediation team included both American and Swiss diplomats and the Swiss Ambassador Josef Bucher acted as the chief mediator. After six days of negotiations, the conflict parties concluded a ceasefire pertaining to the Nuba Mountains on 19 January 2002. It was agreed that the ceasefire in Nuba Mountains would monitored by Britain, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Switzerland and the US. The peace talks in Switzerland were coordinated with IGAD and thus complementary to the IGAD-led peace process.
note_2: IGAD’s Special Envoy to the Sudan Peace Process, Lt. Gen. Lazaro K. Sumbeiywo, witnessed the signing of the agreement, Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the Sudan and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement/Army on Aspects of Structures of Government. IGAD also played a key role at the The Nuba Mountains and Southern Blue Nile Civil Society Forum and Kampala Civil Society Conference, as well as the negotiation and drafting of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement, which included a reinvigoration of the Sudan peace process led by IGAD with the Machakos Agreement.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: Negotiations mediated by IGAD were resumed in Machakos in June 2002. The mediation team at Machakos was led by Kenyan General Lazaro Sumbeiywo. Although Kenya chaired the peace talks, diplomats from Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda were also heavily involved. Moreover, there was active engagement from the four official observer countries in the peace process: the UK, the US, Norway and Italy. As soon as the talks at Machakos started, the conflict parties agreed to extend the ceasefire in the Nuba Mountains for another six-month period.
note_2: IGAD’s Special Envoy to the Sudan Peace Process, Lt. Gen. Lazaro K. Sumbeiywo, witnessed the signing of the agreement, Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the Sudan and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement/Army on Aspects of Structures of Government. IGAD also played a key role at the The Nuba Mountains and Southern Blue Nile Civil Society Forum and Kampala Civil Society Conference, as well as the negotiation and drafting of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement, which included a reinvigoration of the Sudan peace process led by IGAD with the Machakos Agreement.

agreement name: Machakos Protocol
notes_1: On 20 July 2002, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan signed the Machakos Protocol. The peace agreement stipulated the general procedures for a transitional process, but also committed the conflict parties to engage in further negotiations to specify the terms of the framework.
note_2: IGAD’s Special Envoy to the Sudan Peace Process, Lt. Gen. Lazaro K. Sumbeiywo, witnessed the signing of the agreement, Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the Sudan and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement/Army on Aspects of Structures of Government. However, the parties were invited to Washington for informal talks on 19 and 20 December 2002. The US became more involved during 2002. In addition to attending and organising peace talks, it had issued the Sudan Peace Act. This act authorised the President of the US to seek a UN Security Council resolution for an arms embargo and to actively seek other financial and diplomatic methods to influence the conduct of the Sudanese Government. The US held out the prospects of trade and development aid opportunities, as well as a normalization of relations.

IGAD-negotiations, led by the chief mediator Lazaro Sumbeiywo, continued in 2003 throughout the entire year. The US, the UK, Norway and Italy all had observer status during the talks and took part in the mediation. Norway also funded the peace talks. The Arab League announced in May 2003 that it would also begin attending the peace talks as an observer. Ambassador Samir Hosni, Director of the Arab-African cooperation at the Arab League subsequently attended the meetings. In spite of some clashes in early 2003, negotiations started on 23 January 2003. The talks focused on power and wealth sharing.

agreement name: Peace Agreement
notes_1: The implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding on Cessation of Hostilities signed on 15 October 2002 was further improved during a round of negotiations in February 2003, with the signing an addendum to the MOU on 4 February 2003, which created a Verification and Monitoring Team (VMT). The VMT consisted of international observers to verify accusations of ceasefire violations. The conflict parties also agreed to cede control of areas captured since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in October 2002. With regard to the issue of power sharing, the conflict parties agreed on a framework of a government of national unity in which the SPLM/A would be a major partner.

The conflict parties also agreed to cede control of areas captured since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in October 2002. With regard to the issue of power sharing, the conflict parties agreed on a framework of a government of national unity in which the SPLM/A would be a major partner.

In late 2002, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) and the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) took up arms against the Sudanese government. On 14 March 2003, the Darfur based SLM/A stated in a press release that it shall fight for a secular Sudan with a decentralised form of governance, using armed struggle as one of the means to achieve this political goal. By the time this press statement was released the armed conflict had already begun. One of the first organized attacks took place as early as June 2002, when Darfurian rebels targeted a police station in Golo. Yet, it was not until March 2003 that the armed conflict escalated, when several coordinated armed attacks led by SLM/A leader Abdel Wahid were launched on various government army units. When the armed opposition groups took up arms, the Sudanese government initially kept the communication channels open. For instance, after the attack on the police station in Golo in June 2002, the Sudanese government dispatched the chairman of the Parliament’s Transport Commission, Idris Yusuf, to negotiate with the armed groups.  From March 2003 onwards, when attacks on government targets became more frequent, the Governor of North Darfur, Ibrahim Suleiman, formed and ad hoc Darfur Security Committee to negotiate an end to the violence in Darfur. However, this peace effort was terminated as soon as government officials had successfully negotiated the return of commander of the Sudanese air force Ibrahim Bushra, who had been captured during the attack on El Fasher airbase.

agreement name: Abéché Ceasefire
notes_1: In late August 2003, Chad acted as mediator during talks between the Sudanese Government and the SLM/A in Abéché, under the auspices of President Idriss Deby. After five days of negotiations, the conflict parties signed a ceasefire agreement on 3 September. Directly after the talks, Sudan released 54 rebel prisoners as part of the deal. However, only a few days later, the SLM/A accused the Government of Sudan of breaking the ceasefire, which the latter denied. A month later, the SLM/A released 42 prisoners. The Abéché Ceasefire Agreement also called for comprehensive peace talks.
note_2: Chadian president, Idriss Deby, oversaw the proceedings that led to the Darfur Ceasefire, signed by members of the Government of Sudan in Khartoum, the Sudanese Liberation Army, and the Chadian Minister of Public Security and Migration, Mr. ‘Abd al-Rahman Musa.

notes_1: Consequently, official negotiations – which came to be known as the Abéché Ceasefire renewal talks – started on 29 October 2003, one day prior to the ceasefire which had been negotiated on 15 September would end. During these talks, the Chadian Government proposed a draft peace agreement. The talks ended without any results, mainly because the SLM/A demanded the presence of international monitors in Darfur, while the Government of Sudan rejected this.

A closed-door round of pre-negotiations between several Chadian generals and a SLM/A delegation led by Minni Minnawi took place in N’djamena on the evening of 28 November 2003 in preparation of the scheduled formal peace talks the next day. However, based on this meeting, President Déby cancelled the scheduled negotiations last minute, accusing the SLM/A of unrealistic demands.
On 15 December 2003, the conflict parties met once more for negotiations in Chad, but the talks broke down after less than 24 hours.
A round of negotiations between the NDA and the Sudanese government, mediated by Saudi Arabia, in early December led to the conclusion of a framework agreement in Jeddah on 4 December 2003.

The armed opposition groups agreed to this, but the Sudanese government suddenly aborted these talks.” In late March 2004, peace talks between the Government of Sudan and the two rebel groups SLM/A and JEM began in N’djamena in Chad. Chad mediated these negotiations. However, both the SLM/A and JEM were dissatisfied with the mediation by Chad, whom they considered too biased towards the Government of Sudan. The Government of Sudan initially refused to hold face-to-face talks. Yet, when the SLM/A threatened to walk out of the negotiations, the Government of Sudan gave in and sat down with the rebels.

In early March 2004, senior AU officials held consultations with Sudanese government officials in Khartoum to discuss mediation by the AU. On the basis of these consultations, the AU initiated pre-negotiations between the Government of Sudan on the one side and the SLM/A and JEM on the other side in May 2004. The director of the AU Department of Peace and Security, Ambassador Sam Ibok, had been mandated by the AU Chairperson and President of Mali, Alpha Konaré, to act as the AU chief mediator at these talks.

agreement name: Peace Agreement
notes_1: "The talks in May 2004 resulted in an agreement on the establishment of a Ceasefire Commission and the deployment of 130 observers in Darfur that were stationed at five locations in Darfur and one location in Chad. The observers came from AU countries, but also from the US, the EU, and the warring parties themselves. The documents were signed at Abuja on 28 May." agreement name: Protocol on the Improvement of the Humanitarian Situation in Darfur
notes_1: The director of the AU Department of Peace and Security, Ambassador Sam Ibok, had been mandated by the AU Chairperson and President of Mali, Alpha Konaré, to act as the AU chief mediator at these talks. The talks in May 2004 resulted in an agreement on the establishment of a Ceasefire Commission and the deployment of 130 observers in Darfur that were stationed at five locations in Darfur and one location in Chad. The observers came from AU countries, but also from the US, the EU, and the warring parties themselves. The documents were signed at Abuja on 28 May.   The second round of what came to be known as the Abuja talks started in Abuja on 23 August under the auspices of President Olusegun Obasanjo, the chairman of the AU. These talks resulted in the Protocol on the Improvement of the Humanitarian Situation in Darfur, signed on 1 September by the Government of Sudan, the SLM/A, and the JEM. This round of negotiations ended on 17 September.

The parties met between 11 and 21 December for the fourth round of the Abuja talks, which ended with a promise of the conflict parties to commit to the ceasefire agreement signed on 8 April and the Humanitarian and Security Protocols from November, as well as a promise to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict.

A round of negotiations between NDA and the Government of Sudan took place in Cairo in October in 2004 under the auspices of Egypt. The negotiations continued with different rounds throughout the year.

agreement name: Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period
notes_1: Throughout 2004, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan held negotiations in Kenya based on the process agreed on in the Machakos Protocol singed in 2002. The continuous negotiations resulted in the signing of several protocols and agreements that were to make up the foundation of the final Comprehensive Peace Agreement. During a round of negotiations in Naivasha in January 2004, the Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period was signed on 7 January 2004.

Sumbeiywo, witnessed the signing of the Agreement on Permanent Ceasefire and Security Arrangements Implementation Modalities between the Government of Sudan (GOS) and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement/People's Liberation Army (SPLM/SPLA) During the Pre-interim and Interim Periods. The Kenyan cities of Nairobi and Naivasha played hosts to the Sudanese and South Sudanese peace negotiations across 2004 and into 2005, including for talks culminating in the Declaration on the Conclusion of IGAD Negotiations on Peace in the Sudan. Nairobi hosted talks, which culminated in the Nairobi Declaration on the Final Phase of the IGAD-led negotiations on Peace in Sudan. agreement name: Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period
notes_1: Throughout 2004, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan held negotiations in Kenya based on the process agreed on in the Machakos Protocol singed in 2002. The continuous negotiations resulted in the signing of several protocols and agreements that were to make up the foundation of the final Comprehensive Peace Agreement. During a round of negotiations in Naivasha in January 2004, the Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period was signed on 7 January 2004.

conflict sub-locale: South Kordofan; Nuba Mountains; Blue Nile; Abyei
agreement name: Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Southern Kordofan/Nuba Mountains and Blue Nile States; the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Abyei Area; and the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on Power Sharing
notes_1: The next round of talks in May 2004  resulted in the signing of three agreements in Naivasha on 26 May: the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Southern Kordofan/Nuba Mountains and Blue Nile States on 26 May 2004, the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Abyei Area on 26 May 2004, and the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on Power Sharing on 26 May 2004. The conclusion of the three agreements finalised the political negotiations. The only issues that still needed to be addressed were the more technical issues of a comprehensive ceasefire, security arrangements, and the implementation of the peace agreement. However, during the two months after signing of the three peace agreements, the Government of Sudan claimed to be too busy with the situation in Darfur.

agreement name: Declaration on the Conclusion of IGAD Negotiations on Peace in the Sudan
notes_1: On 19 November, the government and SPLM/A signed a Memorandum of Understanding, committing the conflict parties to sign a comprehensive peace agreement no later than 31 December 2004.

agreement name: Declaration on the Conclusion of IGAD Negotiations on Peace in the Sudan
notes_1: On 19 November, the government and SPLM/A signed a Memorandum of Understanding, committing the conflict parties to sign a comprehensive peace agreement no later than 31 December 2004.
note_2: The Special Envoy to the Sudan Peace Process and Ambassador of the Kenyan Government to Sudan, Lt. Gen. Lazaro K. Sumbeiywo, witnessed the signing of the Agreement on Permanent Ceasefire and Security Arrangements Implementation Modalities between the Government of Sudan (GOS) and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement/People's Liberation Army (SPLM/SPLA) During the Pre-interim and Interim Periods. The Kenyan cities of Nairobi and Naivasha played hosts to the Sudanese and South Sudanese peace negotiations across 2004 and into 2005, including for talks culminating in the Declaration on the Conclusion of IGAD Negotiations on Peace in the Sudan. Nairobi hosted talks, which culminated in the Nairobi Declaration on the Final Phase of the IGAD-led negotiations on Peace in Sudan. The Special Envoy to the Sudan Peace Process and Ambassador of the Kenyan Government to Sudan, Lt. Gen. Lazaro K. Sumbeiywo, witnessed the signing of the Agreement on Permanent Ceasefire and Security Arrangements Implementation Modalities between the Government of Sudan (GOS) and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement/People's Liberation Army (SPLM/SPLA) During the Pre-interim and Interim Periods.

notes_1: Consequently, talks between Garang and Taha resumed again on 7 December 2004 and continued until Christmas Eve. The parties marked the end of the conflict on 31 December 2004 by the signing of a permanent ceasefire.

agreement name: N’djamena Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement
notes_1: The negotiations that started in late March 2004 led to the signing of the  N’djamena Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement on 8 April 2004, stipulating among others a 45-day cessation of hostilities, the release of prisoners of war, and the facilitation of humanitarian access to Darfur. The ceasefire agreement also called for the deployment of a monitoring team to observe compliance with the ceasefire. The Government of Sudan also committed to neutralizing the armed militias during the negotiations. All parties violated the ceasefire agreement at numerous occasions throughout the year.
note_2: The African Union and Chad co-mediated talks to end the Darfur conflict, which escalated in 2003.

note_2: The EU participated in the mediation effort the resulted in the N'djamena Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement.

agreement name: Humanitarian and Security Protocols
notes_1: The third round of Abuja talks started on 21 October, resulting in the signing of the Humanitarian and Security Protocols on 9 November.

agreement name: Humanitarian and Security Protocols
notes_1: The third round of Abuja talks started on 21 October, resulting in the signing of the Humanitarian and Security Protocols on 9 November.

The parties met between 11 and 21 December for the fourth round of the Abuja talks, which ended with a promise of the conflict parties to commit to the ceasefire agreement signed on 8 April and the Humanitarian and Security Protocols from November, as well as a promise to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict.

agreement name: The Comprehensive Peace Agreement (Naivasha Agreement)
notes_1: Minister of International Development on behalf of the IGAD Partners Forum (IPF), H.E. Ms. Hilde F. Johnson, and Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Alfredo Mantic, were witnesses to the Naivasha Comprehensive Peace Agreement on behalf of the IGAD Partners Forum (IPF).

conflict sub-locale: South Kordofan; Nuba Mountains; Blue Nile; Abyei
agreement name: The Comprehensive Peace Agreement (Naivasha Agreement)
notes_1: Special Representative of the UN Secretary General in the Sudan, H.E. Jan Pronk, was a witness to the Naivasha Comprehensive Peace Agreement on behalf of the United Nations

agreement name: Peace Agreement
notes_1: Following a round of negotiations from 14 to 16 January 2005, under the auspices of the Government of Egypt, the conflict parties signed a peace process agreement in Cairo on 16 January 2005. This framework agreement outlined the issues involved in reaching a comprehensive peace and complements the SPLM/A peace agreement of the same month and year. It calls for abolishing emergency laws and statutes restricting freedoms, establishing new laws for Sudanese political parties, methods of allowing for power sharing, and the dissolution of NDA forces. The agreement set up a number of commissions to discuss these issues in order to reach a comprehensive peace agreement.

agreement name: Cairo Agreement
notes_1: A round of negotiations in June 2005 subsequently led to the signing of a full peace agreement on 18 June 2005, referred to as the Cairo Agreement.
On 22 September 2005, the NDA joined the Government of National Unity and the parliament of Sudan following discussions between June and August 2005 on the basis of the Cairo agreement.

The first meeting in 2005, held in Chad in February, was supervised by Chadian President Idriss Deby and attended by international mediators and the Chairperson of the African Union Commission Alpha Oumar Konaré.
note_2: The African Union and Chad co-mediated talks to end the Darfur conflict, which escalated in 2003, holding talks in Abuja. In July 2005, the parties accepted a Declaration of Principles outlining a resolution to the conflict. However, there was much factionalism among the SPLM, hindering the progression of the talks. The mediators and Western powers funding the process placed a deadline for the end of talks, 30th April 2006, by which point a Comprehensive Peace Agreement would have to be signed. Chad was a central mediator to the negotiations over Darfur.

agreement name: Declaration of Principles
notes_1: In May 2005, Salim Ahmed Salim, the former Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity, was appointed as the AU Special Envoy for the Darfur Talks and chief mediator. Salim Ahmed Salim mediated a round of negotiations in Abuja between 10 June and 5 July 2005. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the “Declaration of Principles” on 5 July 2005, after more than three weeks of negotiating. The declaration included provisions for refugees to return home and new security arrangements. It also committed the signatories to respect the different ethnic and religious groups in Sudan and work towards an equitable distribution of national wealth.
note_2: The African Union and Chad co-mediated talks to end the Darfur conflict, which escalated in 2003, holding talks in Abuja. In July 2005, the parties accepted a Declaration of Principles outlining a resolution to the conflict. However, there was much factionalism among the SPLM, hindering the progression of the talks. The mediators and Western powers funding the process placed a deadline for the end of talks, 30th April 2006, by which point a Comprehensive Peace Agreement would have to be signed.

notes_1: A sixth round of AU-sponsored peace talks began in September. Yet, these negotiations were plagued by rebel divisions and violence on the ground. The sixth round ended 20 October 2005.
note_2: The African Union and Chad co-mediated talks to end the Darfur conflict, which escalated in 2003, holding talks in Abuja. In July 2005, the parties accepted a Declaration of Principles outlining a resolution to the conflict. However, there was much factionalism among the SPLM, hindering the progression of the talks. The mediators and Western powers funding the process placed a deadline for the end of talks, 30th April 2006, by which point a Comprehensive Peace Agreement would have to be signed.

notes_1: The seventh and final round of talks mediated by the AU started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. From the start of the seventh round of talks, the pressure on the conflict parties to sign a peace agreement steadily increased. The Western governments funding the peace process warned the parties that funding for the peace process could dry up in the absence of progress during the talks. The meetings of the seventh round of negotiations were held at different locations, but finished again in Abuja. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006.
note_2: The African Union and Chad co-mediated talks to end the Darfur conflict, which escalated in 2003, holding talks in Abuja. In July 2005, the parties accepted a Declaration of Principles outlining a resolution to the conflict. However, there was much factionalism among the SPLM, hindering the progression of the talks. The mediators and Western powers funding the process placed a deadline for the end of talks, 30th April 2006, by which point a Comprehensive Peace Agreement would have to be signed.

agreement name: Darfur Peace Agreement
notes_1: A number of high-profile diplomats arrived in Abuja on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hr extensions to the talks’ deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US’s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N’djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and an assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. In spite of the pressure put on the conflict parties to sign the peace agreement, the JEM and the SLM/A led by Abdul Wahid refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the DPA on 5 May 2006. From the signing of the DPA on 5 May 2006 onwards, AU mediators Alex de Waal and Sam Ibok met with SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid several times a day to get clarity on his objections to the DPA. They encouraged him to write to Salim Ahmed Salim a letter in which he could specify on what was needed in order for him to sign the DPA. In his letter send to Salim on 10 May, Abdul Wahid proposed to conclude a ‘supplementary agreement’ to the DPA, demanding greater representation at the legislature and executive bodies of Darfur, as well as a larger compensation fund for Darfur. However, Salim knew that the chief government negotiator, Majzoub El Khalifa, would reject this option, instead insisting that Abdul Wahid had to sign the DPA first, after which some of the remaining issues could be negotiated. Consequently, on 13 May 2006, Salim replied to Wahid that the AU could not re-open negotiations on the DPA, but was willing to support the conflict parties in implementing the agreement. Sam Ibok subsequently tried to persuade Wahid that the AU’s insistence on implementation rather than concluding a supplementary agreement would still allow Wahid to get what he wanted. Ibok’s effort to persuade Wahid did not work. Wahid kept insisting on a supplementary agreement. The AU Peace and Security Council decided on 16 May 2006 that the non-signatory groups would have another two weeks to sign the DPA.

notes_1: A final mediation attempt was launched by the EU during the last week of May 2006, but Abdul Wahid in the end did not show up for negotiations. Instead, he flew to Asmara, Eritrea, at the invitation of JEM leader Khalil Ibrahim to discuss the founding of a rebel alliance.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the USA alongside European powers sponsoring and funding talks held in Abuja to bring an end to the Darfur conflict.

notes_1: Salva Kiir engaged in negotiations with Sudanese government officials mediated by the US in Washington on 20 July 2006. In August 2006, the SPLM/A and Sudanese government forces clashed in the Rubkona area of Unity State, resulting in the death of eight civilians and three soldiers. Heavy fighting between the SPLM/A and government forces in Malakal from 27 to 30 November 2006 resulted in at least 150 people dead.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to to the attempt at mediation.

notes_1: A final mediation attempt was launched by the EU during the last week of May 2006, but Abdul Wahid in the end did not show up for negotiations. Instead, he flew to Asmara, Eritrea, at the invitation of JEM leader Khalil Ibrahim to discuss the founding of a rebel alliance. In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU. The SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi lost power and the movement was now led by Abdul Wahid. The SLM/A refused to attend the UN/AU organised negotiations in Sirtre, Libya. Hence, they were not involved in any negotiations with the Government of Sudan in 2007, although the SLM/A leadership did consult with the UN/AU negotiation team. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassolé assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign-minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no real negotiations took place in 2008 as the warring parties did not meet each other. Abdul Wahid, the leader of SLM/A, demanded that security had to be provided for the civilians in Darfur before he would enter negotiations. Djibril Bassolé continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort in 2009. SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid refused to leave his exile in Paris. Consequently, no negotiations were held between the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan in 2009.In 2010, Djibril Bassolé continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort. In contrast to several of the other rebel groups based in Darfur, the SLM/A and its leader Abdul Wahid refused to negotiate with the Government of Sudan until the security situation in Darfur would improve.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to to the attempt at mediation.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: Fighting escalated in Abyei May 2008. Between 13 and 21 May 2008, at least 90 people were killed in Abyei during violence between government forces and the SPLM/A. Negotiations mediated by the UN led to the signing of an agreement on 8 June 2008. This agreement stipulated a new ceasefire and referred the boundary demarcation to the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in The Hague.

agreement name: Darfur Peace Agreement
notes_1: UNAMID mediated between Sudanese Vice-President Ali Osman Taha and Minni Minawi in al-Fasher in September 2008. The mediation effort led to an agreement that committed both sides to the DPA.

With tensions increasing and the referendum on self-determination for Southern Sudan approaching, the AU started to take the lead in mediating the successful implementation of the CPA. To this purpose, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan (AUHIP) was established during a meeting of the AU Peace and Security Council on 29 October 2009. Led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki, the panel was mandated to assist the Sudanese parties in the implementation of the CPA.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishment of the AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan

notes_1: In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU.  However, the JEM refused to attend any negotiations.  In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassolé assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign-minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no negotiations took place in 2008 as the warring parties did not meet each other. JEM resisted negotiations with other rebel groups present and said that they should be the only one representing the Darfur side in the negotiations. The reason they stated for this was that the government could play the rebels against each other if they were represented by several groups. Bassolé went along with this demand by JEM, because he also believed that if the JEM would sign a deal, then the other rebel parties would follow.  In January 2009, after it had been agreed that JEM would be the sole representative of the Darfurian rebels, Djibril Bassolé succeeded in initiating negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the JEM.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to Qatar's attempt to initiate negotiations.

agreement name: Declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement
notes_1: The negotiations took place from January to February in Doha, the capital of Qatar. The negotiations led to the signing of the declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement (CBA) on 17 February 2009. This agreement was supposed to pave the way for more comprehensive negotiations. However, one day after the agreement was signed, JEM positions were bombed by government forces.

agreement name: Declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement
notes_1: The negotiations took place from January to February in Doha, the capital of Qatar. The negotiations led to the signing of the declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement (CBA) on 17 February 2009. This agreement was supposed to pave the way for more comprehensive negotiations. However, one day after the agreement was signed, JEM positions were bombed by government forces.
note_2: The AU-UN chief mediator Djibril Bassolé was witness to the Declaration of Goodwill and Confidence-Building Agreement.

agreement name: Declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement
notes_1: The negotiations took place from January to February in Doha, the capital of Qatar. The negotiations led to the signing of the declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement (CBA) on 17 February 2009. This agreement was supposed to pave the way for more comprehensive negotiations. However, one day after the agreement was signed, JEM positions were bombed by government forces.
note_2: The AU-UN chief mediator Djibril Bassolé was witness to the Declaration of Goodwill and Confidence-Building Agreement.

notes_1: Another round of negotiations took place in November 2009, but these talks took place in Chad and were mediated by Chadian President Idriss Déby, without the involvement of Bassolé. President Déby initiated these peace negotiations between the JEM and the government of Sudan as part of a rapprochement between Sudan and Chad. Accordingly, Déby presented Sudanese government negotiators with the draft of framework agreement that stipulated that in a final peace agreement the JEM should have representation at all governmental levels.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to Chad's attempts at rapprochement with Sudan.

notes_1: In August 2009, UNAMID convened a Round Table meeting of the Parties and Partners of the DPA on the implementation of the DPA. The meeting was chaired by UNAMID Joint Special representative (JSR), Mr. Rodolphe Adada.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to UNAMID's hosting of a roundtable about the implementation of the DPA.

notes_1: On 19 and 20 July 2010, the AUHIP conveyed a meeting in Juba, at which the AUHIP mediators and the conflict parties formulated a framework for future negotiations, including guiding principles, proposals on clusters for negotiations, and the role of outside experts.

With the 2011 referendum held in the next month, the AUHIP once more tried to resolve the conflict over Abyei at a meeting in Juba on 13 December 2010, but this effort proved fruitless as well. This meeting also reviewed progress on post-referendum issues.
Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the JEM, mediated by Chad, took place in N’Djamena on 20 January.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010 mediated by Chad led to the conclusion of a framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010.  Déby had invited Bassolé to N’Djamena to witness the signing of the framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010.The agreement called for a ceasefire, release of hundreds of JEM-fighters that were imprisoned, and set out terms for future negotiations.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010 mediated by Chad led to the conclusion of a framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010.  Déby had invited Bassolé to N’Djamena to witness the signing of the framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010.The agreement called for a ceasefire, release of hundreds of JEM-fighters that were imprisoned, and set out terms for future negotiations.

agreement name: Framework Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement
notes_1: On 23 February, the Sudanese government and the JEM signed an almost identical agreement in Doha, allowing “the Qataris to claim the glory for the deal hatched entirely in N’Djamena” as Alex de Waal puts it. As the host country, Qatar provided material incentives for the conflict parties to make peace through promising to allocate substantial funds for future development projects in Darfur. During the negotiations leading up to the Doha Agreement, Qatar had promised an amount of two billion US Dollars for rebuilding Darfur if the Government of Sudan and the various rebel movements participating in the Doha negotiations were to sign a peace agreement. The agreement did not hold.

JEM left the ongoing negotiations on 3 May 2010, making it clear that it suspended its participation in the Doha process because of the Sudanese army of breaching the cessation of hostilities agreement.
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the break-down of negotiations.

agreement name: Doha Document for Peace in Darfur
notes_1: After many rounds of negotiations in Doha in 2010 and 2011, and two and a half years of negotiations, major parties to the Darfur conflict, namely the Khartoum government and the The Liberation and Justice Movement (LJM), signed the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD). The JEM joined the agreement in January 2013.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: Another round of negotiations starting in early January 2011 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 January 2011. The Episcopal Church of Sudan moderated these talks. On 23 March 2011, fighting erupted between the South Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SSLM/A) led by Peter Gadet and the autonomous Government of South Sudan in the Mayom county in Unity State. Bapiny Monytuil, who would later become the deputy head of SSLA, led these attacks. The SSLM/A operated mainly in the Unity State, but was also involved in clashes in the Upper Nile State. It received support from the Government of Sudan, including weapons, ammunition, funding, and logistical support. On 11 April 2011, the SSLM/A released a document, called the Mayom Declaration, in which it is claimed that the Government of South Sudan has failed.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: On 5 June 2011, the SPLM/A-North clashed for the first time with the Government of Sudan in Kadugli and Um Durein, two towns located in South Kordofan. On 9 June 2011, the SPLM/A-North expressed that it fought to remove the central Government in Khartoum. Abdel-Aziz Al-Hilu, a leading figure in the movement and the former deputy Governor of South Kordofan, stated the SPLM/A-North waged a “battle for dignity to accomplish the fundamental change in the centre.” The conflict in South Kordofan and Blue Nile can be seen as a continuation of the civil war between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A between 1983 and 2005. While fighters from these two areas joined the SPLM/A rebellion as early as 1984. The Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) concluded in 2005 stipulated a referendum on independence for southern Sudan, but this referendum did not apply to South Kordofan and Blue Nile. This provides the background to the SPLM/A-North rebellion. After fighting had started in June, the armed conflict quickly spread to other towns and villages in South Kordofan. In September, fighting also started in the state of Blue Nile, which is located east of South Kordofan, but the fighting in South Kordofan was more intense. The SPM/A-North was supported by the Government of South Sudan. In early June, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel on Sudan (AUHIP) led by former South African president Thabo Mbeki initiated mediated negotiations to end the fighting. SPLM/A-North chairman Malik Agar negotiated for the SPLM/A-North and Ali Nafi for the Sudanese government.This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire on 16 June 2011. Although the conflict parties had signed the ceasefire agreement and were engaged in negotiations, fighting continued throughout June 2011.

agreement name: Addis Ababa Agreement
notes_1: Nevertheless, negotiations in Addis Ababa, mediated by Mbeki, led to the conclusion of an agreement for comprehensive political and security arrangements in the border states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan on 28 June 2011, referred to as the Addis Ababa Agreement. This agreement was signed by Presidential Bashir’s aide Nafie Ali Nafie and SPLM/A-North leader Malik Agar. In spite of the conclusion of this agreement, fighting continued. On 7 July 2011, the government backed out of the agreement with SPLM/A-North.

agreement name: Addis Ababa Agreement
notes_1: Nevertheless, negotiations in Addis Ababa, mediated by Mbeki, led to the conclusion of an agreement for comprehensive political and security arrangements in the border states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan on 28 June 2011, referred to as the Addis Ababa Agreement. This agreement was signed by Presidential Bashir’s aide Nafie Ali Nafie and SPLM/A-North leader Malik Agar. In spite of the conclusion of this agreement, fighting continued. On 7 July 2011, the government backed out of the agreement with SPLM/A-North.

By the end of August 2011, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi mediated talks between President Bashir and Agar. However, the talks did not produce any tangible results. The government announced a unilateral ceasefire for South Kordofan on 23 August 2011, but fighting continued. In November 2011, the SPLM/A-north, SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and JEM formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army from 2011 onwards. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SPLM/A-North are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad.

The AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan (AUHIP), led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki, mediates a round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A in May 2011. This led to the drafting of a Joint Position Paper on Border Security, which forms the basis for a Common Border Zone and creates a Joint Political and Security Mechanism.
The AUHIP mediated another round of negotiations between the conflict parties on post-referendum issues on 13 June 2011.

agreement name: Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area
notes_1: Another round of negotiations on the status of Abyei, mediated by the AUHIP, resulted in the conclusion of the Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area on 20 June 2011. The agreement stipulated a devolution of power to the Abyei Area Administration, with oversight from the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee. In addition, the agreement called for the demilitarization of the Area with the exception of the UN-authorized and Ethiopian-provided Interim Security Force for Abyei (ISFA). The parties also reaffirmed their commitment to resolve the final status of Abyei peacefully, with mediation support from the AUHIP. Although the Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of Abyei Area stipulated, among others that both the SAF and the SPLA needed to be withdrawn from the Abyei Area, the SAF did not give up their control over Abyei.

agreement name: Agreement between the Government of the Sudan and Government of Southern Sudan on Border Security and the Joint Political and Security Mechanism
notes_1: During a round of negotiations, mediated by the AUHIP, on 29 June 2011, the conflict parties formally signed an agreement that drew on the Joint Position Paper on Border Security. South Sudan gained its independence on 9 July 2011. All peace efforts after this date are coded as negotiations between Sudan and South Sudan.

"In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union’s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Sudanese government and the Sudanese armed opposition. A first round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP took solely place between the SPLM/A-North and the Government of the Sudan in Addis Ababa on 26 July 2012. These negotiations focused on political and security issues underlying the continuing conflict in Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan States. The talks were conducted indirectly via the AUHIP, with both sides setting preconditions for engaging in direct talks. The Government of the Sudan insisted that the SPLM/A-North would disengage from South Sudan, as well made it clear that it opposed the return to the Agreement of 28 June 2011.  On 16 September 2012, the AUHIP submitted a draft proposal for a political solution based on the Agreement of 28 June 2011, reflecting views of the conflict parties and the “changed circumstances and current realities on the ground.”  Neither party accepted this agreement."

"In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union’s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Sudanese government and the Sudanese armed opposition. A first round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP took solely place between the SPLM/A-North and the Government of the Sudan in Addis Ababa on 26 July 2012. On 16 September 2012, the AUHIP submitted a draft proposal for a political solution based on the Agreement of 28 June 2011, reflecting views of the conflict parties and the “changed circumstances and current realities on the ground.”  Neither party accepted this agreement."

agreement name: Peace Agreement
notes_1: "In November 2011, the SPLM/A-north, SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and JEM formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. The SRF was supported by the Government of South Sudan.  In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union’s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Government of Sudan and the SRF. Indirect negotiations between the SRF and the Government of Sudan were mediated the AUHIP. These negotiations led to the signing of on an agreement to allow humanitarian assistance in rebel-controlled areas of South Kordofan and Blue Nile on 4 August 2012. Yet, the agreement did not address the conflict issues."

After Qatar offered to open talks up to more rebel groups in Darfur, a splinter group of the JEM stated that it would join negotiations in October 2012. Qatar offered financial incentives geared towards development in Darfur to incentivise rebels' greater cooperation and participation in peace talks.

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "The AUHIP’s mediation efforts in 2013 mainly focused on negotiations between the Government of Sudan and JEM. A round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 10 February 2013."

agreement name: Protocol on the Participation of JEM-Sudan at the different levels of Government and on the Integration of its Forces
notes_1: "Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in March 2013 led to Protocol on the Participation of JEM-Sudan at the different levels of Government and on the Integration of its Forces on 29 March 2013."

agreement name: Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)
notes_1: "Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in April 2013 led to the Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD) on 6 April 2013. This last agreement was based on the DDPD and all its annexes, as well as stipulated additional power-sharing and wealth-sharing provisions. The agreement also stipulated compensation and return of IDPs and refugees and included a permanent ceasefire."

agreement name: Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)
notes_1: "Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in April 2013 led to the Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD) on 6 April 2013. This last agreement was based on the DDPD and all its annexes, as well as stipulated additional power-sharing and wealth-sharing provisions. The agreement also stipulated compensation and return of IDPs and refugees and included a permanent ceasefire."

agreement name: Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)
notes_1: "Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in April 2013 led to the Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD) on 6 April 2013. This last agreement was based on the DDPD and all its annexes, as well as stipulated additional power-sharing and wealth-sharing provisions. The agreement also stipulated compensation and return of IDPs and refugees and included a permanent ceasefire."
"The AU mediated a round of peace talks between the SPLM-North and the Sudanese government on a political solution to the conflict from 23 to 27 April 2013, but these talks ended without agreement."

"At the start of a round of negotiations on 25 February 2014, the Sudanese government accepted the draft framework agreement put forward by AUHIP to cease hostilities and deliver humanitarian aid to civilians in Sudan’s ‘Two Areas’ of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, but negotiations between the SPLM/A-N and the government were suspended on 2 March 2014 because the conflict parties disagreed on how the resolve the conflict."
"The AU mediated another round of negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan on 22 April 2014, but this round of negotiations also failed."

"On 27 January 2014, President al-Bashir announced the creation of a national dialogue to address Sudan’s political instability. On 31 January 2014, Sudan and Chad agreed to send special envoys to meet and encourage Darfur rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement with the Sudanese government, to engage in peace talks.  Several meetings were held throughout 2014 aimed at initiating a formal peace process between the Sudanese government and the SRF. The joint AU-UN Special Envoy, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, met with the SRF leadership in Kampala on 12 February 2014 to discuss the possibility of formal negotiations. To prepare for the national dialogue, the leaders of the SRF and the Umma Party, a Sudanese opposition party, decided to form an alliance at a meeting in Paris on 8 August 2014. They signed the Paris Declaration, calling for national dialogue."

"On 27 January 2014, President al-Bashir announced the creation of a national dialogue to address Sudan’s political instability. On 31 January 2014, Sudan and Chad agreed to send special envoys to meet and encourage Darfur rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement with the Sudanese government, to engage in peace talks.  Several meetings were held throughout 2014 aimed at initiating a formal peace process between the Sudanese government and the SRF. The joint AU-UN Special Envoy, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, met with the SRF leadership in Kampala on 12 February 2014 to discuss the possibility of formal negotiations. To prepare for the national dialogue, the leaders of the SRF and the Umma Party, a Sudanese opposition party, decided to form an alliance at a meeting in Paris on 8 August 2014. They signed the Paris Declaration, calling for national dialogue."

"On 27 January 2014, President al-Bashir announced the creation of a national dialogue to address Sudan’s political instability. On 31 January 2014, Sudan and Chad agreed to send special envoys to meet and encourage Darfur rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement with the Sudanese government, to engage in peace talks.  Several meetings were held throughout 2014 aimed at initiating a formal peace process between the Sudanese government and the SRF.
